key_work.title: The Dry
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy Made Up Stories, Arenamedia, Pick Up Truck Pictures
key_work.brief_description:
The past and present intersect in Robert Connolly’s hit adaptation of Jane Harper’s best-selling novel The Dry.
Detective Aaron Falk (Eric Bana) returns to the drought-stricken town of Kiewarra to find out who really killed the Haddler family, while also wrestling with the mysterious death of his friend Ellie Deacon, 25 years earlier. The two crimes and timelines are entwined with the arid landscape, its harshness evocatively rendered in both sweeping, cinematic shots and intimate details, strengthening the tension of the mystery while also exposing the effects of the climate crisis on rural Australia.
Aside from its critical acclaim, The Dry became the 14th highest grossing Australian film of all time, leading a resurgence of Australian stories at the local box office.

start.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
start.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
start.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

links.description: In Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country Sam Kelly is condemned by the same white townsfolk who idolise another outlaw, Ned Kelly. The Story of the Kelly Gang is screened in the town in the same spot where Sam stands trial in this true story based on Willaberta Jack.

end.title: The Boys
end.creator_credit: Rowan Woods, John Maynard, Robert Connolly, Arenafilm, Australian Film Commission, Premium Movie Partnership and SBS Independant
end.brief_description: Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, ‘The Boys’ is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods. The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house - his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) - treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film ocassionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence. The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won 4 awards at the 1998 AFI Awards - Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source”. Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

end.title: Animal Kingdom
end.creator_credit: David Michôd, Liz Watts, Film Victoria, Fulcrum Media Finance, Porchlight Films, Screen Australia and Screen NSW
end.brief_description: Following the death of his mother, J finds himself living with his estranged family, under the watchful eye of his doting grandmother, Smurf, mother to the Cody boys. J quickly comes to believe that he is a player in this world. But, as he soon discovers, this world is far larger and more menacing than he could ever imagine. J finds himself at the center of a cold-blooded revenge plot that turns the family upside down.

links.description: The Boys is based on a horrific true crime and helped popularised Australian social realist cinema. Both these films feature criminals returning home from prison and tragically disrupting the family dynamic, with Animal Kingdom also inspired by the real-life murders of two police officers.

end.title: The Square
end.creator_credit: Nash Edgerton, Sally Sharpe, Louise Smith, Australian Film Finance Corporation, Blue-Tongue Films, Film Depot Pty. Ltd., Igloo Films, New South Wales Film & Television Office, Elizabeth Mary Moore, Joel Edgerton and Matthew Dabner
end.brief_description: Ray, a construction worker trapped in an unhappy marriage, pursues an affair with his neighbor, Carla. Carla’s husband, Greg, is a mobster who keeps large sums of drug money in their home. With this in mind, Carla comes up with a plan: She and Ray will steal Greg’s money, burn down her house, convince Greg the money was lost in the fire and then run away together. Carla’s scheme, however, doesn’t go off as planned.

links.description: Six years earlier Nash Edgerton’s Australian neo-noir film The Square debuted and was written by his brother Joel. It was Joel’s first feature-length script, followed by his directorial debut The Gift, and another Michôd collaboration The King.

end.title: Judy & Punch
end.creator_credit: Edie Kurzer, Danny Gabai, Michele Bennett, Nash Edgerton, Create NSW, Pariah Productions, Screen Australia, Soundfirm, VICE Media and Mirrah Foulkes
end.brief_description: In the anarchic town of Seaside, nowhere near the sea, puppeteers Judy and Punch are trying to resurrect their marionette show. The show is a hit due to Judy’s superior puppeteering but Punch’s driving ambition and penchant for whisky lead to an inevitable tragedy that Judy must avenge.
